ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Spoken and written Japanese.
How to converse in Japanese formally and informally (casually)

In this course, I practiced speaking, writing and listening to the Japanese Language. I developed my reading ability by learning and utilizing new vocabulary both in speaking and writing. The homework given helped me further develop this aspect of my ability since we were given passages to read from the textbook. New Kanji are introduced and practiced everyday, helping me learn the stroke order for certain Kanji. We also learned several Kanji which helped make the reading of certain texts easier. In terms of writing, I developed my writing skills due to the daily homework we had. Through these homework assignments I was able to practice the new sentence structures and vocabulary we had learned during and outside of class. Moreover, I was able to write about things related to Japanese culture and my everyday life. When it comes to speaking, the majority of the class is dedicated to this skill. I found this to be extremely helpful especially since I can now think and speak in the language based on what we have learned so far in the class. Furthermore, I am able to have a dialogue with my fellow classmates in Japanese to talk about school, and our daily lives. Many of the homework assignments as well as tests also helped us practice our listening abilities which further helped strengthen my understanding and use of the language. Furthermore, in each of these aspect the language, we learned a lot about Japanese culture, manners of speaking, values, and more.
It is directly on par with the syllabus for reference.
Major improvements in speaking, writing, kanji knowledge, and reading comprehension. Wider breadth of grammatical structures to employ in conversation and writing.
Learned more kanji and grammar this semester. I'm excited since I'm starting to be able to say things that I wan to say. TOTALLY RECOMMEND!
I learned a lot of Japanese, and I think my reading and listening skills improved the most! I also learned more about the culture.
I learned new vocabulary words, sentence structures, particles and Kanji characters in this class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class is really well-organized and full of fun. I love this course.
The strength of this class was the huge amount of resources made available to enhance learning.

The strengths of this course is that it places a great emphasis on speaking during each class. The student is expected to study the vocabulary, sentence structure, Kanji, and writing during homework assignments or outside of the class. Once in the class, they put all of this into practice by speaking solely in Japanese during class to their peers and their teachers. The great part about the prompts is that they are relevant to everyday life. For example, we learned how to request a letter of recommendation from a teacher and what the formalities are in that context. Furthermore, the professors are attentive to the tone used during speaking and the vocabulary forms used so they support you in your learning. The course could be improved by providing a bit more practice in the use of tones. Apart from that, this class has done a great job at helping one develop their Japanese language abilities.
Some of the strengths were the oral practice and amount of vocabulary and tenses we learn.
Regular (daily!) and high quality of feedback allows for constant improvement.

Strengths: This course offers a lot of ways to improve your Japanese. Reading, Writing, and Listening, and Speaking . The work is pretty doable if you don't get too behind.

Weakness: No weakness regarding the teaching material or the way that it. was taught. The only improvement that I could think of is that sometimes homework would be posted somewhat later in the day, which might be a little annoying to people that have time to work on Japanese earlier in the day.

Strengths: Stever-sensei is great! She creates a wonderful environment and this was a class I looked forward to everyday! I think the homework and class activities were great for review, prep, and assessment, so I wouldn't change anything. 
Weaknesses: none
Homework daily kept me refreshed on the material. Sensei was really good at teaching us new concepts. There's not really any weaknesses in this course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
Highly recommended. Stever-sensei is the best language teacher at Yale. 
She not only teaches very well, but also cares about her students, always willingly to help. I received clear feedback that greatly improved my learning. Her class is from 9.25 to 10.15 AM from M to F, but I never felt tired. Her class is the best one I ever took at Yale.
Yes I would if the student is interested in learning Japanese.
Yes! The Japanese program is so great and I really recommend taking the class with Stever sensee... she's so amazing!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The constant workload helps you practice and integrate the Japanese language into your everyday life, making it easier to learn the language. Moreover, there is an emphasis placed on each aspect of the language, being the writing, reading, speaking and listening, so that you are able to us each efficiently. The professors are also very focused on supporting students in the learning process. They are there to check your pronunciation, writing, and speaking to help you improve. Furthermore, the language offers clinics, which help you practice the language outside of the classroom as well. Because these are weekly meetings it helps you solidify what you have learned in class outside as well.
If you are interested in rounding out your beginner skills in a useful way, yes.
One thousand times, yes! Stever-sensei is a fantastic instructor, who truly cares about you and your experience in class.
YES.
YES! You learn so much in the first year, and the second semester is better than the first! Stever-sensei is a great person AND professor, so don't pass the opportunity to take class with her!
If you want to learn Japanese, then yes!
